Since I restarted the experiment the other day, it's managed to get through 
about 1500 generations.  It is currently averaging 26 generations an hour, 
which is not bad compared to what it was (less than 2).

Unfortunately, it hasn't gotten anywhere to speak of.  The fitness is 
remaining mostly flat, right down near the bottom where it has been since it 
started.  But then, I knew this was a hard domain...  Which is why I wanted 
to use NEAT:  I wanted to use just the right topology for it!  :)

Right now, there are 7 machines at work and 4 at home working on the 
experiment.  3 of the 4 at home aren't really that fast, either.  Whereas 6 
of the 7 at work are pretty fast.  So I talked to the IT guys at work.  
They're going to let me take my controller machine to work and give it a 
spot in the server room.  That'll reduce the latency in transferring work 
packets to those machines.  I estimate about a 2x increase in processing 
speed once the controller is close to the worker machines and the 
generational latency is eliminated.  That'll be nice.

I'll probably give it about another week or so, and then I'll start worrying 
about whether or not it will be capable of finding a solution to what I have 
asked it to do.  I *know* it is capable of the first task I have asked of it 
(model the pixel inputs).  I'm not so sure about the second part (a 
mechanism for querying that model).

A thought just occurred to me, and I want you guy's input into it.  When I 
split a connection to make a new node, should I be adding a connection to 
the bias input immediately, rather than relying on it to evolve on its own?  
That way it has a means by which it can make the most of that node right 
away?  What do you think?

-- John
